resources.description:
Access to the JRC-Names dataset via the Open Data Portal SPARQL endpoint. 
For example to see all the properties of the jrc-names graph, use this query : 
SELECT DISTINCT ?property WHERE {graph  <http://open-data.europa.eu/jrc-names/> { [] ?property [] . }} ORDER BY ?property   
   
   . Some more specific query examples are provided in the SPARQL endpoint webpage.
resources.name: SPARQL endpoint access

description:
JRC-Names is a highly multilingual named entity resource for person and organisation names (called 'entities') developed by the European Commission’s Joint Research Centre (JRC). JRC-Names consists of large lists of names and their many spelling variants (up to hundreds for a single person), including across scripts (Latin, Greek, Arabic, Cyrillic, Japanese, Chinese, etc.). For example, the spellings Jean-Claude Juncker, Jean Cloud Junker, Jean-Claude Juencker, Жан-Клод Юнкер, جان كلود جونكر, Ζαν Κλοντ Γιούνκερ, 让-克洛德•容克, and many others have all been identified as referring to the 12th President of the European Commission.   
 
The resource is the by-product of the Europe Media Monitor (EMM, see http://emm.newsbrief.eu/overview.html ) family of applications, which has been analysing up to 220,000 news reports per day, since 2004. EMM recognises names mentioned in the news in over twenty languages and decides automatically for each newly found name whether it belongs to a new entity or whether it is a spelling variant of a previously known entity. This resource allows EMM users to display news about people or organisations even if their names are spelt differently or if the news articles are written in different languages and scripts.  

JRC-Names has been available for download since September 2011, consisting of name variant lists and accompanying software. The new linked data edition, accessible through the European Union’s Open Data Portal, offers more information compared to the previously released resource and tool, including: titles and function names that have been historically found next to the person mentions; information about the time period during which name variants and their titles were found; various frequency counts; as well as links to other linked datasets such as DBPedia.
    
INFORMATION ON JRC-NAMES DATA MODEL  

The JRC-Names RDF representation is based on lemon (Lexicon Model for Ontologies, see http://lemon-model.net/ ), a model which allows the expression of lexical information relative to ontologies.  

JRC entities are modeled as instances of DBpedia classes (dbpedia:Person and dbpedia:Organisation) and the multilingual lexicalizations of their names and function names are represented as Lexical Entries of lemon Lexicons. Various other types of (linguistic) information and metadata are expressed using standardized vocabularies (LexInfo, OLiA, ISOCat, Lexvo, DCTerms, etc.). For cases where no already existing vocabulary could appropriately answer the needs, in-house classes and properties were defined ( see resource JRC data model for JRC names). The "JRC-Names schema" gives an overview of how JRC-Names data is modeled.

JRC-Names has links towards the following datasets: DBpedia ( http://dbpedia.org/ ), New York Times Open Data ( http://data.nytimes.com/ ) and Talk of Europe ( http://linkedpolitics.ops.few.vu.nl ).

For further information on JRC-Names, see: https://ec.europa.eu/jrc/en/language-technologies/jrc-names .
title: JRC-Names: Person and organisation spelling variants as found in multilingual news articles
name: jrc-names
contact_address: Via Enrico Fermi 2749, I - 21027 Ispra (VA), Italia

<rdf:RDF xmlns="http://open-data.europa.eu/ontologies/ec-odp-exemple#" xmlns:ecodp="http://open-data.europa.eu/ontologies/ec-odp#" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:dcam="http://purl.org/dc/dcam/" xmlns:dcat="http://www.w3.org/ns/dcat#" xmlns:dct="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" xmlns:ted="http://publications.europa.eu/ted-schema/ted#" xmlns:foaf="http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/" xmlns:owl="http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#" xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:rdfs="http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#" xmlns:skos-xl="http://www.w3.org/2008/05/skos-xl#" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">
    <!--Insert xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" if schema.xsd used for validation rdf -->
    <!-- ODP version :  Release 1.2.2 -->
    <!-- MAIN DATASET DATA -->
    <!-- Dataset, 1..1, dataype URI. Don't fill in the CKAN catalog identifier here -->
    <dcat:Dataset rdf:about="https://ec.europa.eu/jrc/en/language-technologies/jrc-names">
        <!-- ckan-name, 0..1, dataype Literal. This will be the name in then ODP URI of the dataset. 
Note: Use the same name as used in ckan-name of manifest. Name created by data provider -->
        <ecodp:ckan-name>jrc-names</ecodp:ckan-name>
        <!-- Title, 1..1, dataype RDF literal. Can be filled in in multiple translations though-->
        <dct:title xml:lang="en">JRC-Names: Person and organisation spelling variants as found in multilingual news articles</dct:title>
           
<!-- Alternative Title(s), 0..*, dataype RDF literal -->
        <dct:alternative xml:lang="en">JRC-Names</dct:alternative>

       
        <!-- Description, 1..*, dataype RDF literal -->
        <dct:description xml:lang="en">JRC-Names is a highly multilingual named entity resource for person and organisation names (called 'entities') developed by the European Commission’s Joint Research Centre (JRC). JRC-Names consists of large lists of names and their many spelling variants (up to hundreds for a single person), including across scripts (Latin, Greek, Arabic, Cyrillic, Japanese, Chinese, etc.). For example, the spellings Jean-Claude Juncker, Jean Cloud Junker, Jean-Claude Juencker, Жан-Клод Юнкер, جان كلود جونكر, Ζαν Κλοντ Γιούνκερ, 让-克洛德•容克, and many others have all been identified as referring to the 12th President of the European Commission.   
 
The resource is the by-product of the Europe Media Monitor (EMM, see http://emm.newsbrief.eu/overview.html ) family of applications, which has been analysing up to 220,000 news reports per day, since 2004. EMM recognises names mentioned in the news in over twenty languages and decides automatically for each newly found name whether it belongs to a new entity or whether it is a spelling variant of a previously known entity. This resource allows EMM users to display news about people or organisations even if their names are spelt differently or if the news articles are written in different languages and scripts.  

JRC-Names has been available for download since September 2011, consisting of name variant lists and accompanying software. The new linked data edition, accessible through the European Union’s Open Data Portal, offers more information compared to the previously released resource and tool, including: titles and function names that have been historically found next to the person mentions; information about the time period during which name variants and their titles were found; various frequency counts; as well as links to other linked datasets such as DBPedia.
    
INFORMATION ON JRC-NAMES DATA MODEL  

The JRC-Names RDF representation is based on lemon (Lexicon Model for Ontologies, see http://lemon-model.net/ ), a model which allows the expression of lexical information relative to ontologies.  

JRC entities are modeled as instances of DBpedia classes (dbpedia:Person and dbpedia:Organisation) and the multilingual lexicalizations of their names and function names are represented as Lexical Entries of lemon Lexicons. Various other types of (linguistic) information and metadata are expressed using standardized vocabularies (LexInfo, OLiA, ISOCat, Lexvo, DCTerms, etc.). For cases where no already existing vocabulary could appropriately answer the needs, in-house classes and properties were defined ( see resource JRC data model for JRC names). The "JRC-Names schema" gives an overview of how JRC-Names data is modeled.

JRC-Names has links towards the following datasets: DBpedia ( http://dbpedia.org/ ), New York Times Open Data ( http://data.nytimes.com/ ) and Talk of Europe ( http://linkedpolitics.ops.few.vu.nl ).

For further information on JRC-Names, see: https://ec.europa.eu/jrc/en/language-technologies/jrc-names .

</dct:description>

<dcat:distribution rdf:parseType="Resource">

<dct:description xml:lang="en">Definitions of classes and properties defined by JRC for JRC-names where no already existing vocabulary could appropriately answer the needs.</dct:description>

             <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/TR/vocab-dcat#WebService"/>                    
            <ecodp:distributionFormat>application/rdf+xml</ecodp:distributionFormat>
           <dct:modified rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#date">2015-04-01</dct:modified>
            <dct:issued rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#date">2014-11-18</dct:issued>
 </dcat:distribution>    

<dcat:distribution rdf:parseType="Resource">    
<dct:title xml:lang="en">SPARQL endpoint access</dct:title>
<dct:description xml:lang="en">
Access to the JRC-Names dataset via the Open Data Portal SPARQL endpoint. 
For example to see all the properties of the jrc-names graph, use this query : 
SELECT DISTINCT ?property WHERE {graph  <http://open-data.europa.eu/jrc-names/> { [] ?property [] . }} ORDER BY ?property   
   
   . Some more specific query examples are provided in the SPARQL endpoint webpage.

</dct:description>
    <dcat:accessURL rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#anyURI">http://open-data.europa.eu/en/linked-data</dcat:accessURL>
             <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/TR/vocab-dcat#WebService"/>                    
            <ecodp:distributionFormat>text/html</ecodp:distributionFormat>
           <dct:modified rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#date">2015-04-01</dct:modified>
            <dct:issued rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#date">2014-11-18</dct:issued>
 </dcat:distribution>
